heading: 2.1 Specification error in linear regression
text: Linear regression model one fundamental statistical models analyzing relationship pair variables \(Y\) \(\boldsymbol{X}\). classical settings, given linear regression form,\[\boldsymbol{Y} = \boldsymbol{X}\boldsymbol{\beta} + \boldsymbol{\varepsilon}.\]Five assumptions assumed satisfy:\(\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{\varepsilon}|\boldsymbol{X}] = \boldsymbol{0}\)\(\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{\varepsilon}\boldsymbol{\varepsilon}'|\boldsymbol{X}] = \sigma^2\boldsymbol{}\)\(\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{\varepsilon}|\boldsymbol{X}] = \boldsymbol{0}\)\(\boldsymbol{\varepsilon}|\boldsymbol{X} \sim N(\boldsymbol{0},\sigma^2\boldsymbol{})\)\(\boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{X}\) positive definite.Specification error occurs least one assumptions violated. Efforts usually needs made check validation assumptions like believe derived statistical properties linear regression followed presumed underlying data generating process, rather treat linear regression predictive model tries best approximate true relationship \(Y\) \(\boldsymbol{X}\) straight line.

heading: 2.3 Residual plot
text: Among regression graphics, residual plot, specifically, residual versus fitted value plot commonly used examining homoscedasticity linearity assumptions put stochastic error term model.

heading: 2.3.1 Theoretical results
text:
Given fitted linear regression model \[\boldsymbol{Y} = \boldsymbol{X}\boldsymbol{b} + \boldsymbol{e},\]\(\boldsymbol{b} = (\boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{X})^{-1}\boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{Y}\) \(\boldsymbol{e} = \boldsymbol{Y} - \boldsymbol{Xb}\).Proposition 2.1  (Distribution OLS residuals) null hypothesis linear regression model correctly specified, residuals \(\boldsymbol{e}\) follow null distribution\[\boldsymbol{e} \sim N(\boldsymbol{0},\boldsymbol{R}\sigma^2),\]
\(\boldsymbol{R} = \boldsymbol{} - \boldsymbol{X}(\boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{X})^{-1}\boldsymbol{X}'\).Proof. definition residuals \(\boldsymbol{e}\),\[\begin{align*}
\boldsymbol{e} &= \boldsymbol{Y} - \boldsymbol{Xb}\\
&= \boldsymbol{Y} - \boldsymbol{X}(\boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{X})^{-1}\boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{Y}\\
&= (\boldsymbol{} - \boldsymbol{X}(\boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{X})^{-1}\boldsymbol{X}')\boldsymbol{Y}\\
&= \boldsymbol{R}\boldsymbol{Y}\\
&= \boldsymbol{R}(\boldsymbol{X}\boldsymbol{\beta} + \boldsymbol{\varepsilon})\\
&= (\boldsymbol{} - \boldsymbol{X}(\boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{X})^{-1}\boldsymbol{X}')\boldsymbol{X}\boldsymbol{\beta} + \boldsymbol{R}\boldsymbol{\varepsilon}\\
&= \boldsymbol{R}\boldsymbol{\varepsilon}.\\
\end{align*}\]Since assumption, \(\boldsymbol{\varepsilon} \sim N(\boldsymbol{0},\sigma^2\boldsymbol{})\), \[\begin{align*}
\boldsymbol{R}\boldsymbol{R}' &= (\boldsymbol{} - \boldsymbol{X}(\boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{X})^{-1}\boldsymbol{X}')(\boldsymbol{} - \boldsymbol{X}(\boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{X})^{-1}\boldsymbol{X}')' \\
&= \boldsymbol{} -  \boldsymbol{X}(\boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{X})^{-1}\boldsymbol{X}' \\
&= \boldsymbol{R}.
\end{align*}\],
\[\boldsymbol{e} \sim N(\boldsymbol{0},\boldsymbol{R}\sigma^2).\]
\[\tag*{$\blacksquare$}\]Clearly, null hypothesis, residuals heteroskedastic, since matrix \(\boldsymbol{R}\) identity matrix. However, large sample, residuals \(\boldsymbol{e} \approx \boldsymbol{\varepsilon}\).Proposition 2.2  (Consistency OLS estimator) Suppose \[T^{-1}\boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{X} \overset{p}{\longrightarrow}\boldsymbol{G}_{XX} \quad ~n \longrightarrow \infty,\] \(\boldsymbol{G}_{XX}\) positive definite matrix finite elements. \[T^{-1}\boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{\varepsilon} \overset{p}{\longrightarrow}\boldsymbol{0} \quad ~n \longrightarrow \infty.\] OLS estimator \(\boldsymbol{b}\) consistent, \[\boldsymbol{b} \overset{p}{\longrightarrow}\boldsymbol{\beta} \quad ~n \longrightarrow \infty.\]Proof. Given OLS solution 
\[\begin{align*}
\boldsymbol{b} &= (\boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{X})^{-1}\boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{Y} \\
&= (\boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{X})^{-1}\boldsymbol{X}'(\boldsymbol{X}\boldsymbol{\beta} + \boldsymbol{\varepsilon}) \\
&= \boldsymbol{\beta} + (\boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{X})^{-1}\boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{\varepsilon}.
\end{align*}\]Thus, Slutsky’s theorem probability limit \(\boldsymbol{b}\) \[plim(\boldsymbol{b}) = plim(\boldsymbol{\beta}+ (\boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{X})^{-1}\boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{\varepsilon})=\boldsymbol{\beta}+\boldsymbol{G}_{XX}^{-1}\boldsymbol{0}=\boldsymbol{\beta}.\]\[\tag*{$\blacksquare$}\]suggests, difference \(\boldsymbol{b}\) \(\boldsymbol{\beta}\) small large sample size. Therefore, difference \(\boldsymbol{e}\) \(\boldsymbol{\varepsilon}\) also small large sample size, 
\[\boldsymbol{\varepsilon}\overset{approx}{\sim} N(\boldsymbol{0},\sigma^2\boldsymbol{}).\]
